text: okay let's let's get started because we all want to go right
um hello everyone um thank you for coming you're the ones who are seeing ndc
through to the bitter end i applaud you and more importantly i thank you i thought i was going to do this to an empty room so i am super grateful
um so my name is dale i'm a developer for ibm with a background in ai and machine
learning this is going to be essentially an intro to ai machine learning talk but
hopefully with a bit of a difference i'm going to be giving an intro to ai machine learning talk through the eyes
through the lens through the experiences of school children because i spend a lot of time doing work
with local schools um i go into schools and i run computing classes machine learning
classes i teach children aged 7 and up about what machine learning is and what it's all about i'm not this
photo actually isn't from a school because i'm not allowed to go to school and take photos of the children they get a bit weird about that um so this is
from mozfest um an event from a couple years ago and that's my daughter running a machine learning workshop and i was
running around being her happy helper but what i'm going to be doing is telling you about things i've seen school children do and
how they've sort of stumbled onto some really fundamental lessons about ai and machine learning
so let's a bit of context to get started with this is scratch um if you haven't
seen it before this is used around the world to teach coding to kids
the idea is programming concepts are represented as these blocks on the palette and the kids drag them onto the
canvas and they snap together and that's how they make their programs and this gives kids this like friendly accessible
approachable sandbox that they can learn about coding in so what i've been doing is putting
machine learning models in scratch by adding it to that palette so kids can do what they used to and make their
programs but like this these blocks represent imagenet now if you haven't used imagenet before it's a machine
learning model that you give it up an image and it tells you the object that's in that image so they can make things
like this that tell them you know there's a pekingese in that photo and a baseball in that one and a brown bear in that one
with just you know that many blocks or this one which is using a face detection model
spot my daughter again um so a few sprites here a nose and an eye and an eye and each one is following finding
the location of something on her face so with a tiny little bit of coding she made this like emoji masky facey thing
so what did they learn what do the kids learned from doing this um it was really intentional using scratch
to do machine learning lessons i didn't want to build a whole new tool and teach the kids a different way of
doing things so they could do a machine learning because what they learned from this well firstly there's a pragmatic
thing right it means i don't have to teach them how to use a new tool because they all learn scratch in school they all know what scratch is so that gives
me a big head start but more usefully this sends a message to them that machine learning in ai isn't replacing
their need to learn code it's not me coming into the school and saying you know your teacher's been teaching you the scratch code stuff don't worry about
that because ai is coming and ai is going to magically figure it all out instead what the kids learn is machine
learning is adding to what they've already learned it's it's a new tool in their toolbox
it's extending what they can do with code it's not replacing it but giving them existing machine
learning models is nice but really what i like to get the kids to do is to train their own machine learning models
so i built a whole load of tooling around getting the kids to make really simple uh supervised learning models so
what they do is they create these like buckets representing classes and they fill it with training examples and they
use this to train a machine learning model and they can do this for text and pictures and sounds and numbers and all sorts of stuff
um so what they're doing here is making a chat bot um they were learning about the moon so
they they came up with some ideas of what questions they thought someone might ask about the moon like how big it is what's it made of um what's the
temperature on the moon that sort of thing and they filled each of those buckets with lots of examples of how they would ask that question
they then use that to train the machine learning model and then they're back into scratch because when they jump in scratch their model is represented with
these new blocks and then they can script what answers they want their bot to give when it recognizes an answer
and then what you see there is they ask what's the temperature and the bar answers so
what they learn from this kind of thing is the workflow of of how an ai project
works a machine learning project works the idea of predicting what commands you think the user is going to give
creating those buckets and then collecting examples of how someone would give those commands so filling in uh
filling in each of those buckets with all those examples and then using those examples to train a machine learning model and then scripting the responses
of what they wanted it to do when the system recognized the intents and more than that that idea of you know
when it gets things wrong go back to the training examples add new training examples train a new model go back try
it out it gets it right that cyclical workflow of how machine learning model projects uh tend to go
so by by doing this for themselves even in a small scale like a lesson or so they start to get a feel for how ao
projects go how they work um this is a fun project we made a
pac-man game a really simple one so that the buckets are the moves um going left going right going up going down and each
one is filled with examples of where pac-man was and where the ghost was uh well we were doing nano and monsters to
you know copyright um so what happened is uh they train a model so that the machine learning model
can take control of the little pac-man character and then drive it around the game now because you know primary school
kids they're only like nine or ten so we did a really simplified version of pac-man so only one ghost and not many
walls in the way just to keep it nice and simple but the principles basically the same right so what they had is this
pac-man character that can navigate around the maze and try and avoid that
so what did they learn from this well um one interesting thing is you give them a
little time to collect training data and then they try it out and their pac-man is rubbish it just runs straight into the ghost or it dives into a corner and
gets stuck there so then you say well give it a bit more training a few more training examples training a bit longer
then try again and they see it lasts a little bit longer and then gets caught so then a bit more training um and it it
lasts a bit longer and the more training they give it the longer and longer it can evade the ghost until the point where it actually gets perfectly able to
just keep avoiding the ghost forever so what do they learn that correlation between the quantity of the more
training data you give it the better the accuracy tends to be and that quantity of training data having a really major
impact on the performance of the machine learning model i really like using games with kids
for this sort of stuff so another project i've done really similar is knots and crosses so um
same sort of idea you collect training examples of all the possible moves uh you know in pac-man there are four
possible moves go up down left right in norton crosses there are nine so there's a bit more training data
so this takes ages so what do they do well one of the classes i did this with sort
of suggested well instead of all of us all 30 kids each of us training our own separate machine learning models why don't we all work together why don't we
all put our training examples into one project and then we'll have hundreds
of examples really really quickly i thought it's a great idea so yeah let's do it let's give it a try so we set up one project and they all started
putting their training examples into there and really really quickly they had a machine learning model that if it didn't win every game it would at least
force a draw so what did they learn from that um the idea of crowdsourcing for training
data a really common uh aspect of a lot of successful machine learning projects i've worked on in the real world is
how we collect training data by trying to do it at scale with a large number of users or even gamification you know the
nice thing about the pacman one was they didn't have to type in their training examples they weren't typing in the coordinates we played the game right you
get them to play pac-man and every time they press the button to control the pac-man it was adding a training example into one of their training buckets in
fact actually getting them to do a lot of training data wasn't a problem getting them to stop collecting training data and get on with the lesson that was
a bit more of a problem this project i did with some slightly
older kids they were doing some stuff around media literacy they were learning about how different media outlets different news outlets covered the same
sort of stories and the different ways different media outlets use language
so we wanted to see if we could train a computer to recognize some of those patterns so they they picked four
national newspapers in the uk and they got the main front page headline the top story the top headline
from that newspaper for each day and collected a load of examples and then we used it to
make this little game where you give it a new headline you type in a headline and it will try and predict
which newspaper that headline probably came from and then it puts the newspaper on the right shelf
so when we started in that i was sort of getting them to to type in a headline that they'd already used in the training
and then i sort of ask them well do you think that's a good test like have you proven that the computer has really learned how to make a prediction if
you've already told it that headline came from that newspaper and they were like oh no that doesn't really prove it also what should we do
well why don't we pick new headlines that we've never shown the computer before then we really know if it's learning that's a that's a better test
and i tend to use metaphor so i sort of ask them you know when you're doing your tests at the end of term does the
teacher give you questions she's already told you the answers to or does she give you new questions to check if you've learnt it and then the kids go oh well
it's new questions that we haven't seen before and that's how the teacher really knows if we've understood it well that's what we do with computers
too the idea of needing to separate out training and test data is a lesson they tend to sort of work
out for themselves this is a fun project
you tell the kids to create two buckets one for the nicest kindest loveliest compliments they can think of and one
for the meanest cruelest nastiest insults they can think of generally this bucket stays empty that
bucket gets full really quick and i've learned some new words um it's this is a risky one with older kids
i've done this with teenagers and i've learned all sorts of language um but what do they learn from this there's
an often an assumption that machine learning with text it's about training the computers to understand what the text means
but it's it's not just about meaning it's not just about intent you know computers learn to spot patterns in the examples that we give it and those
patterns could be around intent but it could be about writing style formal or informal it could be about uh emotional
happy sad or like this you know around sentiment so that idea of uh being able to train a computer to recognize
different kinds of patterns in groups of text um but what we do with this one is so we train
um the computers to recognize a compliment or an insult we go into scratch and then
we get them to make a character um normally i'll get them to draw it themselves because particularly the younger kids they like being creative
but i can't draw so i went with an emoji instead so you type in a new message that it hasn't seen before either
something nice or something mean if you say something nice it changes the costume and it looks happy if you say
something mean you dumb it cries and then obviously all the boys
spend the rest of the lesson trying to make the face cry but hopefully what they learn is you
know like i said machine learning can be used to recognize lots of different types of patterns in the examples we
give it but also about different uses of machine learning like creating systems that can respond appropriately based on
the emotional reaction of the user
um alexa or siri or or google home those kinds of devices
quite often there's at least a few kids in the class who've got one of them at home and even the ones who haven't got one at home have seen it before and are
aware of it so it's a nice thing to get the kids to create um because it's a use case they're familiar with so
we create a couple of examples you know turn on the fan turn on the lamp they fill those buckets with examples of how they would give that command and then we
make a virtual alexa an alexa that only knows how to do two things turn on a fan and turn on a lamp but they can phrase
that command in natural language in english please turn on the fan for me and then the fan animates
and it's a nice way of of giving them some insight so that alexa isn't this magic black box in the corner of the
room they start to get some idea about how it was made what went into it that workflow that i was talking about before
but the nice thing with this is because it's a use case they're familiar with you can use this to sort of tease out interesting ideas so one thing i've done
with this is like you come up with a really obscure way of phrasing it right so you ask the thing
like for the fan activate the spinny thing or something that's something that's a bit weird
something that they haven't really trained how to cope with that so it's something that gets it wrong so then it gets it wrong like you tell
it activate the spinny thing and it turns the lamp on so you sort of say well what do we do now how are we going
to fix that and you prob them a bit and they sort of go well what about if we go back to the training examples and add
that to the bucket so that next time it learns how to get that right good idea let's try so we go back add it
to the training buckets we try again and it starts getting it right that kind of insight
i think is lacking in the general public because when i see stories like this
that amazon are getting examples of things alexis get wrong and people are labeling those examples
and putting them into training data as someone who's been working machine learning for a long time i go well yeah
of course they are because that's how machine learning projects work but apparently that's a big surprise to
most of the public so one of the nice things about doing these kinds of projects with schools is
now by no means am i saying i tell the kids that this makes it okay and actually it's a really interesting
conversation once they understand the idea and the motivation behind it you can have that discussion of well do you think it's appropriate do you think they
should be doing that do you think they should tell you when they do that how should they tell you and kids have a great sense of what's fair and what's
right and what's wrong but if they're coming from an understanding of the motivation of the tech companies who do
this they're able to have that debate in a way that i don't think the media really are
sticking with the alexa one the other thing that that this lets kids do is play around confidence scores because
those of you who've done machine learning stuff before we'll know that machine learning models don't just give you an answer they give you a score like
a percentage of how confident the system is that it's correctly understood your question so here what it's doing is
the the class has got the it's checking the confidence and if it's less than 50 confident it recognizes the input it
just says i don't understand um so you can ask it things like make me a sandwich or what's the capital city of
france or you know something like that and instead of just turning on the lamp or the fan
it will say sorry i don't understand the idea of the confidence scores and
the way that we use them and again trying to use examples with what the kids will have seen already um so like
when they ask siri something and it says sorry i don't understand how did it know it didn't understand that like giving
them some idea of what went into that is really helpful
they also start to because the tricky bit is how do you know that 50 is a good number
um so getting the kids to experiment with that threshold what happens if you set it really high what if you make that 99
well it says i don't understand to everything it like it never confidently turns on a fan or a lamp it just goes oh
i'm not sure what if you make that number five well it never says i don't understand it
always thinks it's got an answer and does it um and getting the kids to try and find that for themselves and to get
them to describe it i thought was really interesting i had a fantastic um a bunch of students described this as
being like if they set the number too high they
described that as the computer was being shy essentially they thought the computer was being timid they said it was like
when they knew the right answer when the teacher asked a question but they weren't confident enough to put their hand up because they weren't sure if
they were right which i thought was the best metaphor like way better than anything i could have come up with and a
really nice way of of sort of describing that and it means you can have those
discussions in the class about well there is no one number threshold that you should use it
depends on the project because it kind of depends on how risky like is it okay if you get something wrong occasionally
for some sorts of projects a high number is appropriate for some a low number is and getting the kids to see that for
themselves i found really interesting but there are other ways of using confidence scores as well
i did this project with a slightly older group um so we were training it to recognize lego
figures right so you'd hold a lego figure in front of the webcam and it would say in this case doctor who right
and that one had a really high confidence because we'd only trained it to recognize like four or five different lego figures
um but i asked the class well why does it what part of that picture did the
computer think was really important um and they were like no because machine
learning models are a black box annoyingly i'd already told them that so they could use that against me and go you told us it's a black box we can't
work it out it's like one no don't give up so quickly um but intuitively do you
think this corner down here is why i thought that's the doctor and they were like oh no of course not well
are you sure can we prove that so we had a bit of an experiment we played around with covering up
different chunks of the picture and we looked at what that did to the confidence score so when we covered up the top left confidence score hardly
changed at all when we covered up his foot the confidence dropped to 56 percent that
really surprised me i was not expecting his his left foot to have such a major
impact um when we covered up his chest like with with with the jumper and stuff i thought that would have a major impact
it it dropped the percentage like confidence by about 20 so we wrote a little thing in scratch
and i'd say it's fantastic the kids know scratch so they know how to do this stuff we did it so that it moved the box
it tried every different position of the box and then we made a visualization by changing the
transparency of the box based on the difference it made to the confidence and it made that
so suddenly at the start of the lesson i was like do you know what part of the picture made the computer think this was doctor who and they were like you can't
tell well you can sort of tell and this is done by primary school kids
which i think is fantastic in different ways of dealing with that challenge of a black box and how we can try to infer
what the computer is thinking uh it's a lesson that i think there are some adult developers could do with learning
i do engineer some things that i know i want the kids to learn at the start the lesson so i do try to trick them into
stumbling into some things it's always more fun if i don't do that but sometimes like this you can probably tell where i'm going with this we
trained it to recognize apples or tomatoes and we collected a load of photos of apples and a load of photos of tomatoes
can anyone tell where i'm going with this yeah exactly
they did see they didn't see it coming so we showed it like you say a red apple
and unsurprisingly it stuck most of the red apples in with the tomatoes
and similarly found really unripe green tomatoes and it put them in with the apples but once the kids see
that happen initially they're surprised they're like oh hang on what um but then you ask them well why do you think it's done that and of course they'll
immediately spot it um so you ask them well how do we fix this well maybe if we go and find some photos
of red apples and green tomatoes add that to the training then we try and yes it gets it all right
there was one time when this happened that it wasn't engineered by me which was much better um i was getting them to
make um [Music] like a an ai sheep dog so this idea that it
would take it would learn to recognize cow or sheep and then we made this game in in scratch that would move the animals to the right part of the field
because i thought that'd be kind of cute because i thought like ai sheepdog would be fun
but what i hadn't thought is there were there was a couple of kids that had done like this photos for all
their training examples and then when they were doing the test for the sheep dog bit they had loads of cartoon images
of cows and sheep and it was getting most of them wrong putting them in the wrong place so but it ended up being a
great learning opportunity for the class because i could sort of say well why do you think it's getting them wrong it was like oh we never taught it how to
recognize cartoons we only taught it how to recognize photos how do we fix that let's get a load of
uh cartoons and stick it in the training examples and then try it and it works so that idea of what happens when you
test with things that weren't represented in the training what happens if you try to get the machine learning model to do something that you haven't
taught it how to do before haven't trained it how to do before and how it typically ends up getting a lot of things wrong um it's been really
interesting to see the kids learn that for themselves
slight variation on that i've done this project loads of times rock paper scissors get the kids to hold their hand
up to the webcam in the shape of a rock or paper or scissors once they've trained it to recognize their hand we make a game in
scratch where they play rock paper scissors against the computer and it's kind of fun like i said games work well keeps the kids motivated
one of the times i did this lesson um there was one kid who did a really good job with rock and scissors he had a nice
like he did a really good job of uh varying his training examples because there's always some keen kids who hold
their hand still and hammer the take photo button and end up with 10 virtually identical photos and their models are rubbish because there's no
variation but this could have done a good job rock and scissors were good but when he was taking photos of paper his
mate had come around and stood next to him and his mate was in the shot of the webcam so in all of his paper photos it
was a hand and a person in all of his rock and scissors photos it was a picture of a hand
and he didn't he didn't notice that it wasn't intentional he didn't pick up on it and then when he was testing it when he'd made his game any time me or the
teacher came and stood next to him the computer thought he was doing paper and it was like it took us so long to
figure that out it's like 10 minutes of scratching our heads and why is it doing that and when we when the penny finally dropped it was literally he would hold
his hand up and computer would think rock and then i would jump in and it would go paper and then i'd go away and it would go rock again
um and i love that like i say it's so much better when i don't engineer these lessons because
what they learned was the computers machine learning systems learn from patterns in the data we give it those
patterns might not be the patterns you'd intended it to learn from it might not be what you'd initially set out for it to it to learn but they will learn from
examples in the data you give it and this is something that like we making the real that kind of mistake we make in
the real world all the time um
this project we did was around making recommendations for places people might want to go on
holiday so we came up with a few buckets of museum and fun fair and theme park and a
fishing pond um filled it with examples of what people would describe as their hobbies
and interests and then we made this little phone app that you would sort of say you know i would like
to relax and it would go try going fishing so they you know they make this and it works really nicely and you have a bit
of a discussion about how machine learning is commonly used in recommendation engines um you know it's
how spotify can recommend what you might want to listen to how youtube recommends what you might
want to watch next how amazon recommends what you might want to buy
what i liked with this project what i've done with with some of the older kids is
get them to go back and add so we've already got a fun fair add a
theme park so you've got two kind of similar things and then get them so that the funfair
bucket has like two or three examples in it and get them to put
40 examples in the theme park bucket so it's really unbalanced and then when they start asking their
app i want to do something exciting theme park i want to i want an adrenaline rush
theme park i want to go on rides theme park it never says fun fair and then you ask them well why is it never answering
with funfair and they visually see in the training buckets that you know they've got
loads of examples in one bucket and hardly any in the other and normally with a bit of nudging and a
bit of prompting they go oh well i've told it the right answer is fun fact i've hardly ever told you the right answer is fun fair but i've told it the
right answer is theme park loads of times so the computers learn that the right answer is normally theme park
that's a really like that's a penny dropping moment that's because often the kids come into the class with
this assumption that the good algorithms the smart code the smart algorithms give the right answers
and the rubbish algorithms and the rubbish technology gives the wrong answers the whole idea that actually
these systems are influenced not just by the quality of the code and the algorithms but by who's trained it and
what they use to train it with that really surprises them most of them never see that coming
that idea that just by the person who's choosing the examples they feed the model with has that level of influence
over the what answers the system gives that really surprises them and i think to a non-technical
non-developery person that that isn't initially intuitive so then you ask them well what do you
think about that is that okay you're happy with that and it's an app telling you where you can go on holiday so they're like
you go well what if what if the reason why the fun fair bucket is hardly empty is mostly empty
and the theme park bucket is really full what if that was because the owner of the theme park gave you a big sack of cash to put loads of examples in there
is that okay at that point some of them will come off the fence they're like okay that doesn't
seem fair but most of them are still it's a holiday app who cares so then you go okay what if this wasn't
recommending places to go on holiday what if this was recommending the best medicine for you
and the buckets were drugs from different drug companies and the reason why you put loads of examples of medical
records in one bucket and not many and the other is because the manufacturer of that drug gave you a sack of cash
at that point they're all off the fence they're all oh hang on would that happen is that how that works
and you're having a debate about transparency in ai with a bunch of 10 year olds
and that need for transparency in the way these critical systems these systems have a massive impact on our lives and
you know how do we know what went into training these systems and who influenced what went into training these systems and how
these systems are being used by doing this for themselves by being able to bias a machine learning model
for themselves and seeing how easy it is to do it and the way that the technology
behaves like i said kids have a fantastic sense of fairness and justice and right and wrong and you can have really interesting debates with them
about that after they've sort of had a little bit of exposure to what's possible
i like doing projects based around sound so if it makes for a really noisy lesson but
you can get them to do little sound recordings um so with this one
like we just i got the kids to invent new words because the machine learning model already recognizes words in the
english dictionary so i get them to come up with like secret code words secret code noises for a few different places
in town and then they make a game where when they say the code word the spy goes
to the secret place so it's kind of fun but what's interesting is when we
make something like this so this is a game where when she shouts out laser eyes
it finds where her face is using that face detection model i mentioned earlier and it fires lasers out of her eyes and
she has to smash the bottles this is a fun one because you end up with a room full of kids screaming laser
eyes but what what i like about this and what they learned from this is this idea that
typically it's not just about one machine learning model for one project what we do is we assemble a collection
of machine learning models that all do different kinds of things into a solution so this one is using the face detection model i talked about a while
ago which is sort of just off the bottom there and the sound recognition one where she created a bucket and filled it
with sound recordings of her shouting laser eyes but that idea of how we combine
multiple models to do a single job um often again they don't initially realize
they just assume that an app is going to use a model to do one thing and that's the app's job
this is another one that i that i engineered so i got half the class to train a model
to recognize different types of fruit i got the other half of the class to train a model to recognize different
types of animal didn't tell them why just you're making a model to recognize fruit
you're making a model to recognize fish insects or birds and then we made this out of it where we
gave it raw shack pictures and we used both models this half of the classes and this half the classes at once
and one half of the class given the same picture their model said it's a plum god knows why and there one said it's a

same picture the other mod thought it was a fish so you ask them
why is it doing that i mean that isn't a banana that isn't a fish why is your model doing that and they would go well
yeah but we didn't teach it what that was and you said well why do these two machine learning models the same
technology why are they giving different answers like well that one was only taught to recognize these things and that one was only taught to recognize
those things there's a reason why i was making the class do that is because i've just seen this in the news does anyone see this
project a couple years old now for those who haven't seen it before um it was a project where

loads and loads of scenes from horror films and what this does is it you give it a picture and it classifies it as something from a horror film
so it would do stuff like this they would give it raw shack pictures and it would go this looks like a man

how this ai is a psychopath and why why have we disturbed this poor
technology they force-fed you literally they force-fed this ai a stream of
macabre images from horror films and they've made it into a psychopath
comes back to what i'm saying before that give the kids a little context and it gives them an idea about how it helps
them to recognize when the media is portraying ai in certain ways it helps them to understand what's going on under the covers
because ultimately what we're talking about is what happens when you ask a machine learning model to do something it wasn't trained to do norman was
trained to recognize scenes from horror films so if you show a rorschach picture all it's going to do is give you an
answer that has been taught how to give something from a horror film
this one was a fun one we one of the ways we can collect the training examples is by drawing directly
onto an on-screen canvas so i got them to write examples of postcodes of zip codes onto the canvas for a few local towns
near us so load of examples of oxford guilford and southampton and then we
made uh a postman pack game in scratch something where you would write onto an on-screen
envelope and it would recognize what they'd written and then send that envelope to the right van
so like for this one you could write the the code for oxford scribble that on they click on the cat
stamp their machine learning model that they trained would recognize what they've written and the letter goes to the right place
now partly this is just a nice little tech demo right it's a fun little thing it's teaching them about handwriting
recognition optical character recognition it's a fun project
but what i liked about it was that it gave me that chance to talk to
them about how this is how it's a simplified version you know a cut down version but it's a version of how
sorting officers have automated the sorting of envelopes and packages and stuff
and that idea that ai is everywhere you know invisible ai it's not just the systems that they do
notice like alexa and siri the fact that all of our days are impacted in 101 tiny
ways that we don't even notice by these ai systems projects like this i i like because it
helps open the kids eyes up to um it helps them to spot where uh these places
where ai and machine learning is being used my last fun one
we did a project with books so we picked a few different genres of books and we trained a machine learning model
to recognize um you know what a music book looks like and what a cookery book looks like what

um and then we made an app that would you show it a new book that it hasn't seen
before and it would tell you which shelf in the library that book should go on to
and the main reason i like that is just because uh it meant that we could teach the kids that yes a computer can learn
